Inference: High usage frequency indicates a heavily utilized fixture
Description: If usage logs show many sessions per day, that faucet or shower is a primary point of use in the household or facility.
short rationale: Reveals central fixture use tied to daily routines.

Inference: Low usage frequency suggests secondary or rarely used fixture
Description: Very few usage events over long periods imply the fixture is backup, guest-only, or located in a low-traffic area.
short rationale: Indicates secondary role with limited personal detail.

Inference: Long average session duration implies comfort- or relaxation-oriented use
Description: If typical sessions last significantly longer than a few minutes, the fixture is likely used for extended activities such as full showers rather than quick rinses.

Inference: Short average session duration indicates quick, task-focused use
Description: Mostly brief sessions suggest functional activities such as handwashing, quick rinsing, or short utility tasks.

Inference: Morning peaks in usage times reveal hygiene-based daily routines
Description: Usage clustering in early hours across many days indicates regular morning routines such as brushing or showering before work or school.

Inference: Evening peaks signal end-of-day unwinding or pre-sleep rituals
Description: Frequent usage around late evening suggests users prefer to shower or wash up before going to bed.

Inference: Midday usage spikes indicate at-home schedules or flexible work patterns
Description: If many sessions occur around midday, it hints that occupants are often home at that time or have flexible routines.
short rationale: Indicates daytime presence and schedule flexibility.

Inference: Weekend-dominant usage patterns reveal schedule-dependent demand
Description: Higher counts or longer durations on weekends versus weekdays indicate that water use for personal care increases when people are off work.
short rationale: Shows weekend vs weekday lifestyle differences.

Inference: Distinct weekday vs weekend usage profiles indicate structured work–life separation
Description: Clear differences in timing or duration between weekdays and weekends show that fixture use is tightly coupled to work or school schedules.

Inference: Consistent daily timing suggests highly routinized behavior
Description: When usage times are tightly clustered at similar clock times each day, it reflects fixed daily habits such as a regular shower time.

Inference: Highly variable daily timing indicates flexible or irregular routines
Description: If usage events are spread widely across different times day-to-day, routines are less structured or occupants’ schedules are irregular.
short rationale: Indicates irregular schedules with lower identifiability.

Inference: Increasing total daily usage duration indicates rising water demand
Description: A long-term upward trend in total minutes used per day suggests growing usage—potentially due to more occupants or longer sessions.
short rationale: Shows increased demand linked to occupancy or habit changes.

Inference: Decreasing total daily usage duration suggests conservation or reduced demand
Description: A downward trend in usage minutes per day implies shorter sessions, fewer sessions, or occupants spending less time at home.
short rationale: Indicates reduced usage tied to behavior change.

Inference: Long continuous sessions occasionally appearing indicate deep-clean or special events
Description: Rare but very long sessions compared to the norm may correspond to infrequent but intensive tasks such as deep cleaning or long showers after exercise.
short rationale: Highlights rare intensive events and timing.

Inference: Clusters of multiple short sessions in quick succession suggest multi-step tasks
Description: Several short usage events within a narrow time window imply multi-phase routines like wash–rinse–repeat cleaning or staggered tasks.

Inference: Extended periods with no usage indicate vacancy or non-occupancy
Description: Multi-day or multi-week gaps with zero usage logs suggest that the space was unoccupied, such as during travel or holidays.

Inference: Sudden onset of regular usage after a long idle period signals new occupancy or activation
Description: After a long idle stretch, the start of regular sessions suggests new residents, reoccupation, or the fixture being brought into active use.

Inference: Abrupt increase in usage frequency points to added users or changed habits
Description: A step-change from low to high daily session counts likely reflects a new occupant, a change in living arrangements, or a shift in hygiene frequency.

Inference: Abrupt drop in usage frequency suggests users left or switched to another fixture
Description: A sudden reduction in usage after a stable period indicates people may have moved away, changed routines, or started using other fixtures instead.

Inference: Regular overlapping usage at multiple fixtures implies multi-person simultaneous use
Description: If multiple fixtures show usage windows that align in time, it suggests more than one user using water simultaneously.

Inference: Short, frequent sessions throughout the day indicate high-touch hygiene routines
Description: Many small usage events distributed across the day are consistent with frequent handwashing or quick rinses rather than long showers.

Inference: Few but very long daily sessions indicate infrequent but intensive washing patterns
Description: One or two long sessions per day suggest a pattern dominated by full showers or extended washing rather than repeated short uses.
short rationale: Shows intensive but infrequent personal care.

Inference: Different daily usage profiles across fixtures reveal functional differentiation
Description: When one fixture shows short, frequent sessions and another shows fewer, long sessions, it indicates different roles purely from timing and duration.

Inference: Time-of-day shifts in peak usage indicate evolving routine schedules
Description: If the main usage peak moves from one time window to another over weeks, it suggests changes in work, school, or lifestyle.

Inference: Seasonal increase in total usage duration reflects climate or behavioral shifts
Description: Higher total daily or weekly usage durations in certain seasons suggest more frequent or longer showers in response to weather.
short rationale: Seasonal variation with moderate identity risk.

Inference: Seasonal decrease in usage duration indicates reduced water-intensive activities
Description: Lower usage minutes in specific seasons hint at shorter showers or fewer daily uses driven by cooler temperatures or seasonal routines.

Inference: High day-to-day variance in usage minutes signals inconsistent lifestyle patterns
Description: Large swings in total daily usage duration imply irregular schedules, varying occupancy, or occasional high-intensity use days.
short rationale: Indicates inconsistent lifestyle without precise identity.

Inference: Stable daily usage minutes indicate consistent household behavior
Description: When total daily usage time remains within a narrow band for long periods, household routines are highly stable and predictable.
short rationale: Stable behavior pattern that aids profiling.

Inference: Usage density around specific time slots suggests bottleneck periods
Description: If many sessions start or end near particular times, those windows are likely peak demand periods that might impact shared systems.
short rationale: Identifies peak demand times, revealing routines.

Inference: Long tails of late-night or very early usage events indicate off-peak activity
Description: Usage events occurring in very early morning or late night hours point to shift work schedules, late-night habits, or irregular sleep patterns.

Inference: Short sessions with very long gaps indicate low water touchpoints in daily life
Description: A pattern of occasional, very brief uses with long periods of inactivity suggests limited reliance on that fixture in the daily routine.

Inference: Multiple usage bursts per day indicate more fragmented routines
Description: Several distinct usage clusters such as morning, afternoon, and night suggest that daily water-related activities are spread across multiple life segments.

Inference: Consistent pre- and post-event usage patterns show preparation and cleanup phases
Description: If two usage clusters regularly appear around certain times, it indicates preparatory and cleanup cycles in daily life.

Inference: Gradual elongation of sessions over months indicates growing comfort or laxity
Description: When average session length slowly increases without a jump in frequency, users may be spending more time under the faucet or shower per use.

Inference: Gradual shortening of sessions suggests conservation or time pressure
Description: Decreasing session durations over time imply either active conservation efforts or more time-constrained routines.
short rationale: Indicates increasing conservation or time pressure.
